liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has flagged another potential meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping next month. The pair met briefly during last November's G20 summit in Bali, and there is growing speculation Albanese could make his first visit to China as leader before the end of the year. When asked about Beijing's recent decision to lift tariffs on barley, the prime minister has told parliament his government is always open to dialogue with Australia's largest trading partner. "I met with Xi Jinping in November last year, and I'm sure that we will potentially meet again on the sidelines of the G20 meeting that will be coming up in the future," Albanese said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM  flags potential meeting with Chinese President next month

props.alt: A man with an ear piece in is side by side to a man wearing glasses

children.content: Australia's PM has flagged a potential meeting with Xi Jingping in September
(Reuters:  Maxim Shemetov/Jaimi Joy)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ACT government has publicly released the report of the board of inquiry into the prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann. The release comes just days after some of the report's content was published by the media. The inquiry examined the conduct of criminal justice agencies and was led by former Queensland judge Walter Sofronoff. The report accuses the ACT's top prosecutor of generating the inquiry on the basis of "scandalous" and "wholly false" allegations, "without any reasonable basis". You can read more on the findings of the report here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ACT government officially releases report into Bruce Lehrmann's prosecution

featuredLink.title: ACT government publicly releases report from inquiry into Bruce Lehrmann's prosecution

The release comes just days after some of the report's content was published by the media.
The inquiry examined the conduct of criminal justice agencies
and was led by former Queensland judge Walter Sofronoff.
The report accuses the ACT's top prosecutor
of
generating the inquiry on the basis of "scandalous" and "wholly false" allegations, "without any reasonable basis".
You can read more on the findings of the report here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The navy has recorded the highest number of sexual assaults in Australia's Defence force, in a new report released by the Director of Military Prosecutions. AAP reports that the documents reveal there were 47 sexual assault and related offences received by the office last year, up from 30 in 2021. Despite being a smaller service than the army, there were 21 sexual offences received from the navy last year (up from 12 in 2021), with 18 offences in the army (up from right in 2021) and eight in the air force (down from 10 in 2021). Sexual assault support lines: 1800 Respect National Helpline : 1800 737 732 Sexual Assault Crisis Line Victoria : 1800 806 292 Safe Steps Crisis Line (Vic) : 1800 015 188 Men's Referral Service : 1300 766 491 Lifeline (24-hour crisis line): 131 114 Victims of Crime Helpline : 1800 819 817
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Sexual assault claims in the Australian Defence Force rise in latest report

props.alt: A large Navy ship in water

items.synopsis: The ASX is following modest falls on Wall Street on Friday. US markets eased on a slowdown in job creation, although Australian data show there are still plenty of jobs being advertised here. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX follows Wall Street lower, as job ads show there is still plenty of work available in Australia

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This is the second week of reporting season, but week one was very quiet, so it's really the first fairly big week. As I mentioned earlier, there are no major results out today, but Tuesday sees building materials firm James Hardie report. Wednesday is dominated by financial services, notably CBA, which is expected by analysts at Morgans to crack the $10 billion mark for cash profit, up 5.6% for the year. Economists will be watching for any signs that bad mortgage and business debts are on the rise. Suncorp is also worth a watch, after ANZ had its takeover offer for the insurer's banking division knocked back by the ACCC last week. Insurance profits are also a hot topic, with premiums having surged over the past year. Thursday is busy. AMP is always one that a lot of retail shareholders are interested in. QBE will also be scrutinised for its insurance profit margins and premium increases. AGL will likewise face scrutiny due to massive energy price rises, especially after recent upgrades to its profit guidance. Downer EDI has already flagged its bad news of a massive earnings downgrade. Building materials firm Boral will offer some insights into construction materials costs, which have shown signs of easing from recent highs, and the strength of demand in the building sector. Friday is quieter, with takeover target gold miner Newcrest the main point of interest. REA Group may have some interesting commentary on the property market, while Baby Bunting Group will be an early test of retail. Exactly how discretionary are prams, baby seats and onesies? You can keep track of what's coming up with our searchable table of the reporting season calendar (thanks Kate Ainsworth!).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Reporting season ramps up with CBA, AMP, QBE and AGL among the headline acts

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Aged care operator Estia Health's shares were up 25 cents to $3.09 on news that it has accepted a $3.20 a share takeover bid from private equity firm Bain Capital. Bain first approached the company about a buyout in March this year at an initial offer price of $3.00. Estia's board has agreed to the latest offer as it represents a 50% premium to its closing share price of $2.14 on March 21, the last trading day before Bain's initial offer was made. The $3.20 per share cash price will be reduced by any dividends paid out by Estia before completion. Estia says it's permitted to pay up to 12 cents a share in full-franked dividends, which would result in up to 5 cents per share in franking credit benefits to shareholders. A shareholder meeting to vote on the deal is expected to be held in November, with completion of the takeover by the end of this year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Estia Health shares surge 8.8% on private equity takeover deal

children.content: Aged care operator Estia Health's shares were up 25 cents to $3.09 on news that it has accepted a $3.20 a share takeover bid from private equity firm Bain Capital.
Bain first approached the company about a buyout in March this year at an initial offer price of $3.00.
Estia's board has agreed to the latest offer as it represents a 50% premium to its closing share price of $2.14 on March 21, the last trading day before Bain's initial offer was made.
The $3.20 per share cash price will be reduced by any dividends paid out by Estia before completion.
Estia says it's permitted to pay up to 12 cents a share in full-franked dividends, which would result in up to 5 cents per share in franking credit benefits to shareholders.
A shareholder meeting to vote on the deal is expected to be held in November, with completion of the takeover by the end of this year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has shown little sign of shifting from its early trajectory, with the benchmark ASX 200 index still down 0.3% at 7,304 points around 1:45pm AEST. Industrials and health care are still leading the losses, with the big banking and mining sectors also in the red. Real estate, utilities, energy and consumer cyclicals are the only sectors in the black, with 104 stocks trading down to 87 gaining ground among the top 200. Some smaller miners, particularly in the renewable energy/electronics areas of lithium and rare earths, were making the biggest gains. Meanwhile, buy now pay later and payments services firm Block was dominating the falls, down 11.3% to $97.13 as investors remained disappointed by a quarterly trading update delivered at the end of last week. Australian medical device makers Resmed and Nanosonics also on the nose, off 4.6 and 4.1% respectively.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Market showing few signs of change as ASX heads towards modest losses

children.content: The Australian share market has shown little sign of shifting from its early trajectory, with the benchmark

around 1:45pm AEST.
Industrials and health care are still leading the losses, with the big banking and mining sectors also in the red.
Real estate, utilities, energy and consumer cyclicals are the only sectors in the black, with 104 stocks trading down to 87 gaining ground among the top 200.
Some smaller miners, particularly in the renewable energy/electronics areas of lithium and rare earths, were making the biggest gains.
Meanwhile, buy now pay later and payments services firm
Block was dominating the falls, down 11.3% to $97.13
as investors remained disappointed by a quarterly trading update delivered at the end of last week.
Australian medical device makers
Resmed and Nanosonics
also on the nose, off 4.6 and 4.1% respectively.
